0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-russia-senate-idUSKCN1272G0	U.S. lawmaker wants cyber sanctions on Russia after hacking charges	"

WASHINGTON The chairman of a U.S. Senate cyber security subcommittee said on Friday he planned to introduce sanctions legislation over ""Russia's cyber criminals"" after Washington accused Russia of political cyber attacks ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election.Republican Senator Cory Gardner said his legislation would require the Obama administration to investigate those who have engaged in significant actions undermining cyber security and aggressively pursue sanctions when appropriate.
Gardner is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on East Asia
column2: the Pacific and International Cybersecurity.

column1: (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; editing by Grant McCool)"
1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-obama-idUSKCN1272C0	Obama casts early vote for 2016 election during Chicago trip	"
CHICAGO President Barack Obama on Friday cast his ballot for the Nov. 8 election during a trip to his hometown of Chicago.Onlookers cheered as Obama
column2: who was a U.S. senator from Illinois prior to becoming president
column3: entered the early-voting facility in downtown Chicago.A smiling Obama shook hands with the poll workers at the site and thanked them for their ""outstanding work"" before heading to an electronic voting machine.""Now they can't see me
column4: can they?"" Obama asked the workers as he jokingly shielded his machine from reporters standing nearby.

column1: Obama has been campaigning for Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton to succeed him in the Oval Office.

column2: Obama was the first president to vote early. At the time he was running for his second term in the White House.Obama was scheduled to spend the weekend in Chicago. He made the stop at the voting facility in between appearances at two political fundraisers.

column1: (Reporting by Ayesha Rascoe; Editing by Leslie Adler)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-russia-cyber-kremlin-idUSKCN1272DT	Kremlin: U.S. accusations of Russian cyber attacks are 'nonsense' - Ifax	"
MOSCOW Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said on Friday U.S. accusations that Russia was responsible for cyber attacks against Democratic Party organizations were ""nonsense""
column2: Interfax news agency reported.""This is again some kind of nonsense. (Our) website experiences tens of thousands of attacks by hackers every day
column3: Interfax quoted Peskov as saying.

column1: (Reporting by Jack Stubbs; Editing by Robin Pomeroy)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-immigration-idUSKCN1270Z3	Two hawkish anti-immigration groups say consulted by Trump	"
By Luciana Lopez
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Two groups that support far-reaching curbs on legal immigration to the United States and ideological screening of would-be immigrants to test their beliefs say Donald Trump's presidential campaign has consulted them on his immigration policy.NumbersUSA and the Center for Immigration Studies
column2: which for years have denied accusations they harbor radical views on immigration
column3: told Reuters they had met or had telephone calls with either Trump or senior members of his campaign over the past year.Trump's campaign declined to confirm the meetings.Trump
column4: the Republican nominee
column5: has won over millions of supporters with his calls for a wall on the Mexican border and a temporary ban on Muslims entering the country. But the calls have also drawn an outcry from immigrant rights groups and condemnation from abroad. While Trump's immigration proposals push the Republican Party sharply to the right
column6: NumbersUSA and CIS also want to slash legal immigration
column7: going beyond the New York businessman's call to keep it ""within historical norms.""NumbersUSA says on its website that immigrants are the main driver of population growth
column8: take jobs that should go to U.S. workers
column9: and fuel urban sprawl that threatens farmland and wildlife habitats. ""The aim should be to halt all immigration possible
column10: NumbersUSA head Roy Beck wrote in a blog in March.NumbersUSA wants to cut legal immigration to 500
column13: the group's director of content and activism.About a million immigrants obtain legal permanent residence status in the United States every year
column14: according to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. Around 11 million undocumented immigrants were living in the United States in 2014
column15: down from a peak of 12 million in 2007
column16: according to the Pew Research Center.The head of CIS
column18: has argued against legal immigration extensively. Last year he wrote in the National Review that mass legal immigration would end U.S. conservatism
column19: because immigrants tend to have more liberal views on issues like gun rights.

column1: CONVERGENCE OF IDEAS
Beck told Reuters he had met with Trump in New York and had also spoken with people ""at the top"" of his campaign repeatedly since last autumn
column2: when NumbersUSA accepted invitations to meet several Republican presidential hopefuls.Much of the contact was by phone and email. Beck would not provide details of what was discussed or say who took part in the discussions.In early August
column3: NumbersUSA shared a 10-point immigration plan with the Trump campaign. Of the 10 points
column4: six were echoed by Trump in a major immigration speech on Aug. 31.Those points included calls for the immediate deportation of undocumented immigrants with criminal records and the mandatory use of the ""E-verify"" system to check a job applicant's legal status. The Trump campaign declined to comment on the apparent overlap. The policy was written with input from Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama
column5: former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani
column6: as well as Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers and Border Patrol agents.Beck said the overlap showed the ""convergence"" of ideas between his group and the campaign but he acknowledged he had ""no indication that they sat down and looked at our 10 steps and said let's take six of them.""

column1: Based in Arlington
column2: Virginia
column3: NumbersUSA describes itself as the ""the nation's largest grassroots immigration-reduction organization with more than 5 million participants."" It is credited with helping block immigration bills in 2007 and 2013 that aimed to make it easier for undocumented immigrants to become citizens.

column1: EXTREME VETTING""
Krikorian
column2: of CIS
column3: whose slogan is ""Low-immigration
column4: pro-immigrant
column5: said his group had also received requests for research and studies from the Trump campaign for months. In an Aug. 15 speech
column6: Trump outlined his plan for ""extreme vetting"" of immigrants
column7: calling for an ideological test to gauge their views on things like religious freedom
column8: gender equality and gay rights to ensure the country only admits people ""who share our values and respect our people."" CIS was an early proponent of ideological screening - widely criticized as discriminatory and a violation of freedom of thought - to protect U.S. culture and national security following the Sept. 11
column11: but it was unclear if Trump consulted CIS on the idea.

column1: The Department of Homeland Security already requires people seeking legal status in the United States to show they adhere to the principles of the Constitution.Krikorian took part in a roundtable of national security advisers at Trump's New York headquarters in August
column2: after which he said he was asked by Trump's campaign to be a ""surrogate."" A surrogate can act on behalf of a campaign
column3: by speaking at rallies and other events.Krikorian said he turned down the Trump campaign's request. Hate watchdog groups like the Southern Poverty Law Center and the Anti-Defamation League have accused NumbersUSA and CIS of attempting to use mainstream arguments to sell proposals aligned with white nationalism.""These are the organizations that are the leading edge of the nativist movement in this country
column4: said Frank Sharry
column5: executive director of immigrants' rights group America's Voice. Both organizations reject the claims.""We're absolutely opposed to nativism
column7: adding that NumbersUSA's recommendations come from a desire to protect American workers. His group stresses that it blames bad immigration policy and not immigrants themselves.Krikorian said CIS wants ""an ethnically neutral policy that lets in fewer people in the future and does a better job of welcoming those people we do legally admit to our country.""(Adds dropped word
column10: additional reporting by Emily Stephenson and Emily flitter; Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Ross Colvin)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-india-idUSKCN12717J	Trump's Indian-American fan spreads the word back home	"
By Douglas Busvine
| NEW DELHI
NEW DELHI Donald Trump sympathizes with India in its recent escalation of tensions with Pakistan and supports skilled immigration
column2: an adviser said on Friday
column3: portraying the U.S. presidential hopeful as a friend of India and Indian Americans.Trump
column4: a real estate billionaire
column5: has earned a reputation of hostility toward minorities with proposals such as ""extreme vetting"" of potential immigrants and building a wall along the Mexican border to stop illegal immigration. The Republican nominee has proposed a ban on immigration from countries where vetting would be difficult
column6: such as nations faced with Islamic militancy.Some Indian officials worry the United States could become more isolationist under Trump
column7: leaving allies like New Delhi without the support it has enjoyed under President Barack Obama against China's growing regional influence.     Shalabh Kumar
column8: a Chicago-based businessman of Indian origin tasked by the Trump campaign with reaching out to Asian-Americans
column9: said India and the Indian-American community had nothing to fear from a Trump presidency.

column1: There may be only 4 million Indian Americans but the potential to develop the relationship with their country of origin
column2: a land of 1.3 billion
column3: was huge
column4: Kumar told a news conference at a hotel in New Delhi that drew a curious audience of about 30 journalists and several TV cameras.""Our overarching goal is for the 21st century to be an Indian-American century - instead of a Sino-American century
column5: said Kumar
column6: wearing a dark suit and gold-rimmed pilot glasses
column7: his white hair swept back.    ""Mr Trump is a businessman - he has no bone in his body
column8: not a drop of blood that is anti-immigrant
column9: Kumar said. ""He wants to have legal

column1: The Punjabi-born businessman
column2: who emigrated in 1969 and was converted to the Republican cause by Ronald Reagan
column3: also said Trump's determination to keep Islamic militants out of the United States played well with his community. Around four in five Indians profess the Hindu faith
column4: while 14 percent are Muslims. Hindu nationalist groups
column5: including many Indian Americans

column1: There is a war declared on the free world by Islamic terrorists
column2: Kumar said. ""We are very happy that India under Prime Minister Narendra Modi has taken a very firm stand.""Kumar said the Republican Hindu Coalition
column3: a group that he set up last year
column4: would hold a cultural event and charity fundraiser in New Jersey on Oct. 15 at which Trump will deliver a keynote address.Half of the gate receipts would go to victims of terrorism
column5: in particular Hindu refugees from Kashmir and Bangladesh. (Additional reporting by Rupam Jain; Editing by Paritosh Bansal and Nick Macfie)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-regulations-idUSKCN12629R	Republican Trump says 70 percent of federal regulations 'can go'	"
By Chris Kaufman
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump said as many as 70 percent of federal agency regulations could be eliminated if he is elected in November
column2: just hours after an adviser said the candidate would seek to cut 10 percent.    Trump
column3: who blamed regulations for stifling business
column4: told a crowd at a town hall event in New Hampshire on Thursday night that regulations for the environment and safety would remain. ""We are cutting the regulation at a tremendous clip. I would say 70 percent of regulations can go
column5: Trump said. ""It's just stopping businesses from growing.""Earlier in the day during an online discussion with Reuters
column7: a Wall Street financier who has raised campaign money for Trump
column8: said Trump would eliminate 10 percent of regulations.""We need regulation but immediately every agency will be asked to rate the importance of their regulations and we will push to remove 10 percent of the least important
column9: he said.    Another Trump campaign adviser reached by Reuters confirmed the 10 percent regulatory cut was part of their economic plan. Jeff Holmstead
column10: a former assistant administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency under George W. Bush's presidency
column11: said the goal was hard to comprehend.""You could reduce the number of regulations by 10 percent without accomplishing very much

column1: He added it would make more sense for Trump to try to reduce the cost of regulatory compliance by 10 percent.""I think it probably would be possible for a new administration to make changes that would reduce the cost of these programs by at least 10 percent while still maintaining essentially the same level of environmental protection
column2: he said.Officials at the EPA and the U.S. Department of the Interior declined to comment
column3: citing internal policies.Scaramucci also said that Trump
column4: a fierce critic of the Federal Reserve
column5: would probably get along well with Fed Chair Janet Yellen. Trump has repeatedly accused the Fed of serving as a political arm of the Obama White House. He says Yellen has put off raising interest rates in order to let President Barack Obama end his term in January without the economic shock that a rise in interest rates might entail.

column1: Scaramucci
column2: a founder of SkyBridge Capital
column3: joined Reuters Global Markets Forum to discuss his views of the campaign. He said Trump would strive for a better balance in federal regulations.    Scaramucci was not as dismissive of Yellen as Trump is
column4: saying he believes the New York property developer would warm to her eventually.""There are many well-qualified candidates but I think Mr. Trump has to spend some time with chairwoman Yellen. I think knowing what I know about his personality he will like her
column5: he said.Trump would seek to streamline regulations as a way to generate economic growth and help the flow of capital
column6: the adviser said. Trump has specifically singled out the energy industry as an area that he would look at for reducing regulations.

column1: Wall Street is not the devil
column2: said Scaramucci. ""In fact we are at our best when (there) is harmony between Main Street and Wall Street and we hope to restore that.""Scaramucci singled out several areas that Trump would look to for reforms:--Labor Department rules expanding the fiduciary standard for financial brokers who sell retirement products would likely be stopped.--Legislation similar to the former Glass-Steagall Act that limited the banking industry would be on the table for review.-- The Dodd-Frank banking reforms that emerged from the Great Recession of 2008-09 will be reviewed and ""the worst anti-business parts of it will be gutted.""-- The Volcker rule will be adjusted. Named after former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker
column3: it is part of the sweeping 2010 Dodd-Frank financial reform law. It aims to reduce risk-taking by preventing banks from using their own capital to make speculative bets.      (Additional reporting by Jennifer Ablan
column4: Valerie Volcovici
column5: Ginger Gibson and Emily Stephenson; Writing by Steve Holland; Editing by Alistair Bell and Lisa Shumaker)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-guns-idUSKCN1270YO	NRA gun rights group pours money into Republican U.S. Senate campaigns	"
By Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The National Rifle Association is on track for record spending this year on U.S. political campaigns
column2: including Missouri's U.S. Senate race where a gun-owning Democrat is waging a tough fight against an incumbent Republican backed by the gun rights group.Democrat Jason Kander
column3: an Afghanistan war veteran
column4: is running just 2.5 percentage points behind Republican U.S. Senator Roy Blunt in opinion polls in Missouri
column5: despite the NRA's expenditure of $1.8 million so far trying to protect Blunt as well as the Republicans' U.S. Senate majority.Gun violence has transfixed the United States in 2016
column6: from a massacre at an Orlando
column8: nightclub to a rash of police shootings
column9: fueling demands by some Democrats and activists for tighter gun laws.Those efforts have been thwarted
column11: by the NRA and its supporters
column12: who say such measures would infringe on the right to bear arms guaranteed by the Second Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. Congress has not approved major gun-control legislation since the 1990s.An Aug. 19 Reuters/Ipsos poll found 41.8 percent of respondents agreed there should be strong restrictions on firearms and 22.4 percent supported moderate regulations.     Per-capita firearm ownership in the United States far exceeds any other country
column13: according to government estimates.  In the Missouri race and other Senate contests in states such as North Carolina
column16: the gun-control battle gripping Washington is playing out on the campaign trail.The NRA has spent $23.4 million in this election cycle
column17: with a month to go before voting on Nov. 8
column18: compared with a previous high of $27 million in the entire 2014 campaign cycle
column19: according to federal data gathered by the Center for Responsive Politics.The NRA did not respond to requests for comment.In addition to Senate Republicans
column20: the lobbying group is also backing Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump.Blunt
column22: is a two-decade veteran of Congress. He accuses Kander
column24: of being soft on gun ownership rights.

column1: Blunt has an ""A"" rating from the NRA. Kander has an ""F
column2: which the NRA says he earned by backing expanded background checks on gun buyers and legislation that failed this year in Congress to bar people on ""terrorism watch lists"" from buying guns.""The difference between Senator Blunt and myself is that I want to stop criminals and suspected terrorists from having the same access to guns as the rest of us
column3: which is why I support background checks
column4: Kander said in a statement to Reuters on Thursday.'RESET THE DEBATE'

column1: Kander
column2: Missouri's secretary of state
column3: counterpunched against Blunt last month with a 30-second TV commercial that has had more than 1 million views on youtube.com.

column1: In the ad
column2: the former U.S. Army captain assembles a military-style rifle while blindfolded. He says he has supported gun ownership rights
column3: but adds: ""I also believe in background checks so that terrorists can't get their hands on one of these.""A fierce debate in Washington over such background checks in June led to a 25-hour sit-in by Democrats on the floor of the House of Representatives. ""The reaction to that ad has reset the debate"" in the Missouri Senate race
column4: said Tim Daly
column5: managing director of guns and crime policy for the liberal Center For American Progress
column6: a think tank in Washington.Kander's polling numbers were already rising when the Sept. 15 ad was first broadcast. But Daly said Kander planted fresh doubts over the NRA position on background checks.Blunt and his campaign spokesmen were not available for comment.

column1: The NRA is Blunt's No. 2 financial backer in the Missouri race
column2: surpassed only by a group closely associated with U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell that backs Republicans.SENATE MAJORITY AT STAKE

column1: Like the Blunt-Kander battle
column2: other key 2016 Senate races feature intense debate over guns as Republicans work to defend their control of the Senate.In North Carolina
column3: the NRA has pumped in $2.8 million to support threatened incumbent Republican Senator Richard Burr.The first televised debate in New Hampshire this week between Republican Senator Kelly Ayotte and her Democratic challenger
column4: Governor Maggie Hassan
column5: began with a moderator asking how they could reduce gun violence without infringing on gun rights.Ayotte has come under attack from Americans for Responsible Solutions for her opposition to tough gun background checks. The group works to reduce U.S. gun violence in the United States. (Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-cuba-usa-biden-idUSKCN12700I	Jill Biden
column2: wife of U.S. vice president
column3: arrives in Cuba	"

column1: By Marc Frank
| HAVANA
HAVANA Jill Biden
column2: wife of U.S. Vice President Joe Biden
column3: arrived in Cuba on Thursday
column4: the latest sign of the rapprochement between the Cold War foes that saw President Barack Obama and his family visit in March.Biden was greeted at Havana's international airport by Josefina Vidal
column5: who is leading negotiations with the United States as head of U.S. affairs at the Cuban Foreign Ministry.Biden plans to watch a match between the U.S. and Cuban soccer teams on Friday in Havana
column6: go on social media at one of Cuba's new WiFi hot spots and visit a teachers college
column8: according to U.S. diplomatic sources in Havana. Ambassador-at-Large for Global Women's Issues Cathy Russell and Assistant Secretary of State for Educational and Cultural Affairs Evan Ryan are accompanying Biden
column9: who will also travel to central Camaguey province before heading to the Dominican Republic on Sunday.A White House statement said Biden
column11: was scheduled to meet with ""government officials and engage with a diverse range of Cubans on topics related to culture

column1: The Obamas' visit highlighted the warming trend in bilateral relations announced by both countries in December 2014 after 18 months of secret talks and more than a half-century's estrangement.Some U.S. lawmakers strongly oppose the move
column2: arguing that Communist-ruled Cuba must do far more to improve human rights before it can deal normally with the United States.

column1: Agreements have been reached in areas such as law enforcement
column2: the environment
column3: resumption of postal service and commercial flights
column4: while talks on such thorny issues as  fugitives and reparations continue.The decades-long U.S. trade embargo on Cuba remains in place and can only be lifted by Congress
column5: although Obama has used his executive authority to chip away at it.Both sides have said they want to strengthen their economic relationship
column6: but the United States has complained the Cubans have been slow to take advantage of openings carved out by Obama
column9: while Cuba says U.S. sanctions make most trade and investment impossible.

column1: U.S. Trade Representative Michael Froman is also in Havana where he is scheduled to meet on Friday with Foreign Minister Bruno Rodriguez and Foreign Trade and Investment Minister Rodrigo Malmierca. (Reporting by Marc Frank; Editing by Peter Cooney)"
8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-muslims-idUSKCN126256	Trump has shifted away from complete Muslim ban: Pence	"
By Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Donald Trump has backed away from a total ban on Muslims entering the United States
column2: vice presidential running mate Mike Pence said on Thursday
column3: a shift from one of the Republican presidential candidate's most provocative proposals.Trump's call last December for ""a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States"" followed an Islamic State-inspired mass shooting in San Bernardino
column4: California
column5: by a husband-and-wife team.Critics have called the proposed ban discriminatory and probably a violation of the U.S. Constitution's guarantee of freedom of religion
column6: and Democrats have used Trump's policy to declare him a bigot.

column1: In recent months
column2: Trump has said he would suspend immigration from countries where Islamist militants are active but has left vague as to whether this amounted to a narrowing or an expansion of his original policy position.Pence said in a round of television interviews that if elected on Nov. 8
column3: Trump would suspend immigration from ""countries that have been compromised by terrorism.""Asked if this amounted to a ban on Muslims
column4: Pence said on MSNBC's ""Morning Joe"" show: ""Of course not.""

column1: On CNN's ""New Day
column2: Pence was asked why
column3: given that he had been against the ban before becoming Trump's running mate
column4: he was not opposing it now.""

column1: Well
column2: because it's not Donald Trump's position now
column3: replied Pence. (Reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Alistair Bell)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-policy-factbox-idUSKCN1262HR	Factbox: Clinton's policies on economy
column2: Islamic State
column3: other issues	"

column1: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton has pledged to raise taxes on the wealthy
column2: preserve the Dodd-Frank financial reform law and provide a path to citizenship for undocumented workers.	Here are the proposals the former secretary of state has made as part of her argument that she is best qualified to occupy the Oval Office. (For a Factbox on Republican opponent Donald Trump's proposals
column3: please see)ECONOMIC POLICY

column1: Clinton has said the rich
column2: not the middle class
column3: would see their taxes go up.She supports billionaire investor Warren Buffett's eponymous tax proposal calling for those making more than $1 million a year to pay an effective tax rate of 30 percent. Clinton has also called for an additional 4 percent tax on those making more than $5 million annually.Clinton has pledged to raise the estate tax levied on property transferred from a deceased person to their heirs. She also supports a tiered inheritance tax structure
column4: with a top rate of 65 percent on the wealthiest estates of more than $500 million for a single person or $1 billion for a couple.Clinton has pledged to unveil a plan to rebuild U.S. infrastructure during her first 100 days
column5: saying this would create new jobs.She would use some of the revenue generated from her tax plan to pay for making community colleges tuition-free and ensuring students can graduate from public colleges and universities without incurring debt.The Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget
column7: nonprofit group that independently scored Clinton's proposals in their totality
column8: estimated her policies would cost $1.8 trillion over the next decade and would be offset by $1.6 trillion
column9: mostly generated by taxing high earners. The group said the remaining $200 billion could be covered by $275 billion in corporate tax revenue the Clinton campaign has called for but not yet spelled out in sufficient detail for them to credit as an offset at this time.IMMIGRATION

column1: Clinton has promised to propose broad legislation within her first 100 days in office to overhaul the immigration system and establish a process for undocumented workers to become citizens.Clinton has said she will defend executive actions taken by Democratic President Barack Obama to defer deportations of children brought illegally to the United States and the parents of children who are citizens or legal residents. She has said if Congress does not pass comprehensive immigration reform
column2: she will similarly use executive action to defer deportations in ""sympathetic cases.""

column1: A federal court has ruled that Obama did not have the authority to issue his executive orders on immigration
column2: known as DACA and DAPA. The U.S. Supreme Court
column3: currently short one member
column4: split 4-to-4 on whether to hear the administration's appeal
column5: leaving the lower court's ruling in place for the time being.WALL STREET REGULATION

column1: Clinton has promised to preserve the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial reform law enacted after the financial crisis
column2: and to pursue further measures to toughen Wall Street regulations.She has proposed a fee for large financial institutions based on their size and the level of risk they pose. She would also give regulators additional authority to force institutions that pose high risks to break apart or reorganize.Clinton has also urged strengthening the Volcker Rule
column3: which restricts proprietary trading by commercial banks. She has called for a new tax on high-frequency trading and for stricter oversight of hedge funds
column4: private equity firms and other players in the so-called shadow-banking system.She has promised stiffer policies on people who commit financial crimes
column5: including an extension of the statute of limitations on such crimes and a requirement for bank executives to return bonuses if their institutions suffer major losses.

column1: Changes to Dodd-Frank have stalled in the Republican-controlled Congress
column2: and it is unclear whether Clinton could get congressional backing to strengthen the law
column3: unless Democrats win control of one or both chambers in the Nov. 8 election.ISLAMIC STATE

column1: Clinton has pledged to defeat Islamic State and has said the first step to fighting the militant group is to eliminate its strongholds in Iraq and Syria.In a departure from the Obama administration
column2: she supports the establishment of a no-fly zone over Syria and has called for an intensified air campaign by the U.S.-led coalition. Clinton has said she would send additional American special forces to help Arab and Kurdish forces already on the ground. She opposes sending additional U.S. ground troops to the region.Clinton has said the United States and European allies must share intelligence more effectively in order to thwart potential attacks.She has urged Silicon Valley companies to work with the government to track militant recruitment tactics on the internet.

column1: RUSSIA

Current and former Obama administration officials have told Reuters they believe Clinton would  take a harder line on Russia than either Obama or Trump.Clinton has said she believes Russian hackers are behind the breach of Democratic Party systems in an attempt to influence the U.S. presidential election.Clinton has said Russia should play a role in fighting Islamic State in Syria
column2: and her foreign policy adviser has said she would consider arming government forces in Ukraine
column3: one of Russia's neighbors
column4: in a move to combat Russian ""aggression in Europe."" Russia has backed ethnic Russian separatists in Ukraine.CHINA

column1: Clinton was a key player in Obama's ""pivot"" to Asia when she served as his secretary of state from 2009 to 2013.Clinton has said she will ""aggressively pursue trade cases and impose consequences"" against China when it commits trade abuses.She opposes granting China market-economy status
column2: which China will be seeking when a World Trade Organization clause expires in December
column3: and has said she would make sure a newly installed trade prosecutor would ensure that China is playing by the rules.Clinton has said she would treat cyber attacks from countries such as Russia and China ""like any other attack"" and that the United States ""will be ready with serious political
column4: economic and military responses."" (Compiled by Amanda Becker; Editing by Caren Bohan and Jonathan Oatis)"
